program_name: LADWP Demand Response Commercial and Industrial Program
description: LADWP's Demand Response is a voluntary, incentive-based energy management program for commercial and industrial businesses that provides monetary incentives for reducing electrical usage during peak load periods on hot summer days. The program helps reduce utility bills during times of peak power demand while ensuring continued reliability of power for Los Angeles. Participants control their own curtailment procedures and receive both capacity payments (monthly) and performance payments (per event). Since 2015, the program has saved 4,836 MWh and paid approximately $8 million in incentives to participants including commercial customers like Ace Hotel, Anheuser-Busch, and Paramount Pictures.

utilities: Los Angeles Department of Water and Power
geography.iso_notes: LADWP participates in CAISO's Western Energy Imbalance Market (WEIM) since 2021 and has approved joining CAISO's Extended Day-Ahead Market (EDAM) with target entry in mid-2027. However, LADWP retains local control over its generation and transmission assets and ratemaking authority.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Participants must be able to curtail load by 100 kilowatts (kW) or more. Must be able to adjust operations during DR season (June 15 to October 15).

eligibility.front_of_meter_notes: For front-of-meter battery storage, see separate LADWP Commercial Energy Storage to Grid (CES2G) Pilot Program (300 kW-AC on 4.8-kV system or 3 MW-AC on 34.5-kV system). For behind-the-meter battery aggregation, see LADWP Demand Side Grid Support (DSGS) Program.
restricted_resources: on-site cogeneration systems that emit CO2 or other greenhouse gases or harmful pollutants
eligibility.restricted_resources_note: Participants shall not utilize on-site cogeneration systems that emit carbon dioxide (CO2) or other greenhouse gases or harmful pollutants during DR events to meet curtailment commitments, as these systems are not considered eligible resources.
eligibility.aggregator_notes: For battery storage aggregation specifically, LADWP accepts aggregators through the DSGS Program, which requires REST API access to performance data and integration with LADWP's future Distributed Energy Resource Management System.

notification.notification_notes: Participants can choose either day-ahead notification option ($10/kW-month capacity payment) or 2-hour advance notification option ($15/kW-month capacity payment). Notifications for events come from LADWP's Power System department based on peak demand forecasts and resource availability.

seasonal_rates.notes: No capacity payments outside DR season

capacity_rate.notes: Capacity payment is based on committed Peak Load Reduction (PLR) quantity nominated by participant. Minimum 50% performance during DR Events required for capacity incentive payments.

performance_rate.calculation_method: Performance payment is calculated based on actual Peak Load Reduction during each event multiplied by $0.25/kWh. Actual PLR is measured against baseline calculated from average daily usage of three highest of previous ten weekdays, excluding PLR Event Days, weekends and Program Holidays.
performance_rate.notes: Additional event-based incentive payment of $0.25/kWh for actual demand curtailment per event.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No explicit penalty structure found in available documentation. Program is voluntary and incentive-based. Capacity payments require minimum 50% performance during DR Events. Full Performance is defined as Peak Load Reduction equal to or greater than Estimated PLR Quantity for the full PLR Event Duration. Failure to meet minimum performance threshold may result in reduced or no capacity payments, but specific penalty fees are not documented.

payment_structure.payment_calculation_notes: DR performance is calculated after each event and results are shared with participants. Performance data must be measurable in at least 15-minute intervals. Baseline is calculated from average daily usage of three highest of previous ten weekdays, excluding PLR Event Days, weekends and Program Holidays.

seasons.event_limit_notes: Maximum of 20 DR events per season. Limit of one DR event per day. Participants can opt out of maximum of two events per DR season.

seasons.notes: No DR events called during off-season

call_windows.notes: Peak Load defined as electrical load during hours of 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. PST during Demand Response Season. Events occur on weekdays only. Note: Earlier program documentation (2023-2024) specified 1 p.m. to 6 p.m., but 2025 program extends to 9 p.m.

event_parameters.response_time_notes: Response time not explicitly specified but implied by 2-hour or day-ahead notification options
event_parameters.opt_out_notes: Maximum of two opt-outs per DR season allowed

event_triggers.load_threshold: LADWP's load projected to go above certain value and/or annual peak
event_triggers.trigger_description: PLR Events will typically be called for hot summer days when LADWP's load is projected to go above a certain value and/or the annual peak. The Power System department determines when a DR event is called based on peak demand for power and resource availability. Events are called on days with anticipated high demand during the hottest months in L.A., helping to support grid reliability when energy consumption spikes due to high temperatures and increased air conditioning use.
event_triggers.data_quality_note: Specific numerical thresholds (temperature in degrees F, load in MW) are not publicly documented. Triggers are described qualitatively only.

nomination_bidding.nomination_process: Participants file application with LADWP's DR Team specifying Estimated PLR Quantity (in kW). Participants can modify the value of estimated PLR quantity by submitting a new completed application form to Demand.Response@ladwp.com, with the new PLR quantity becoming effective starting the following business day after LADWP's DR Team has received the new application.

enrollment_period.notes: Annual application deadline of May 1 for participation in that year's DR season (starting June 15). After LADWP accepts application, participant is enrolled for duration of participation period (through December 31, 2025) or until written notice to exit program is provided.

performance_measurement.baseline_calculation_method: Average daily usage of three highest of previous ten weekdays, excluding PLR Event Days, weekends and Program Holidays
performance_measurement.telemetry_requirements: Performance data must be measurable in at least 15-minute intervals. For DSGS aggregations, REST API access (or other equivalent data sharing access as approved by LADWP) to performance data for each individual storage and solar device is required.
performance_measurement.verification_method: DR performance is calculated after each event and results are shared with participants. Meter data includes electricity usage in 15-minute interval data format that can be retrieved and displayed in graphical or tabular format.
performance_measurement.minimum_performance_notes: Minimum 50% performance during DR Events required for capacity incentive payments. Full Performance is defined as Peak Load Reduction equal to or greater than the Estimated PLR Quantity for the full PLR Event Duration.

related_programs.description: Market-Aware Behind-the-Meter Battery Storage program for aggregators, requires integration with LADWP's future DERMS/DRMS

related_programs.program_name: Commercial Energy Storage to Grid (CES2G) Pilot Program
related_programs.description: Front-of-meter stationary and mobile battery energy storage systems (300 kW-AC on 4.8-kV or 3 MW-AC on 34.5-kV)

program_evolution.change_description: Call window was 1 p.m. to 6 p.m.
Extended peak load hours to 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. PST. Added restriction on cogeneration systems that emit greenhouse gases.

historical_events_note: Specific historical event dates, times, and conditions are not publicly available. LADWP does not publish a historical event log with specific dates when DR events were called in past years. Program documentation confirms events are called for 'hot summer days' during peak load conditions but does not provide specific event history data.

integration_metadata.optimizer_notes: Program structure is well-suited for battery optimization. Clear payment structure with capacity and performance payments. Predictable call windows (1-9 PM weekdays June-Oct). 2-hour or day-ahead notification provides dispatch planning flexibility. Event frequency (max 20 per season) and duration (max 4 hours) are manageable for battery dispatch schedules. Opt-out flexibility (2 per season) allows strategic participation.
integration_metadata.api_notes: LADWP requires REST API access for DSGS aggregations. Future integration planned with LADWP's Distributed Energy Resource Management System (DERMS) or Demand Response Management System (DRMS) for automated dispatch. 15-minute telemetry interval required.
integration_metadata.data_quality_explanation: Good quality data on payment rates, event parameters, eligibility, and program structure. Well-documented capacity and performance payment rates. Clear nomination and enrollment process. Comprehensive terms and conditions available. Moderate quality on event triggers (qualitative descriptions without specific thresholds). Missing data: specific temperature/load thresholds for event triggers, historical event dates/times, exact response time requirements, specific penalty structure beyond performance minimums, forward pricing curves. No publicly available historical event log to validate actual program behavior.
integration_metadata.notes: LADWP is a municipal utility serving Los Angeles with local control over generation, transmission, and rates. Participating in CAISO WEIM since 2021 with EDAM entry planned for mid-2027. Program has strong track record (10 years, 4,836 MWh saved, $8M paid). Notable participants include major commercial/industrial customers (hotels, breweries, studios). Restrictions on fossil-fuel cogeneration align with California's emissions reduction goals. Program allows participant-controlled curtailment procedures, providing operational flexibility.

research_summary.researcher_notes: Comprehensive research conducted across multiple LADWP official sources and third-party documentation. Program structure is well-documented with clear eligibility, payment rates, and enrollment procedures. Payment structure is straightforward: $10-15/kW-month capacity + $0.25/kWh performance. Event parameters are clearly defined: max 20 events, max 4 hours each, 1-9 PM weekdays June-October. Key data gaps: specific trigger thresholds and historical event data not publicly available. These would require direct contact with LADWP DR Team (Demand.Response@ladwp.com) for operational planning. Program appears well-suited for battery optimization given predictable structure, advance notification, and opt-out flexibility. Notable evolution: program expanded call window from 6 hours (1-6 PM) to 8 hours (1-9 PM) in 2025, increasing potential revenue opportunity but also requiring longer discharge capability.
research_summary.verification_status: All data points extracted from official LADWP sources or authoritative third-party documentation. No data invented or estimated. Fields marked 'not specified' or 'not available' represent genuine data gaps in public documentation.
